description: Repeated authentication success for samantha.thornton using PLAIN over TLS from same IP, could indicate use of valid compromised credentials.
Repeated login for the same user and IP within the same second; abnormal behavior for human-driven access; likely automation or credential abuse.
Same user and IP successfully logging in multiple times across different logs with close timestamp; likely credential abuse.
Multiple successful logins using the same user and IP within one second indicates brute force or automated credential validation.
Sustained login activity from same IP and user with incrementing firedtimes count strongly suggests automated credential use.
Continuation of login pattern by same user/IP confirms suspicious persistence, likely valid account exploitation.
Identical login details repeated in multiple logs—possible persistence or lateral movement using valid credentials.
High frequency of identical successful logins with consistent metadata suggests possible malicious session reuse.
ClamAV update routine; not an attack, standard antivirus database update.
Login success from a different IP/user but matching suspicious pattern seen earlier; likely additional compromised account.
Multiple successful logins for user damian.jordan using IMAP with method PLAIN and source IP 192.168.128.195. Indicates possible use of compromised credentials.
Same user (damian.jordan) logging in again at same timestamp with identical session details. Possibly repeated log entries across log sources or rapid session reuse.
Same session and login details as previous line, appearing in another log file (/var/log/syslog). Indicates log duplication rather than unique events.
New login session for damian.jordan with different session ID and process ID, occurring at the same second. Pattern may indicate automation or script use.
Duplicate of the previous login but from a different log file. No new activity seen. Repeated logging across different log sinks.
Repeat of previous login with same session ID and credentials across another log file. No new attack vector indicated.
Identical login seen again in syslog; multiple log sources reporting the same event.

Duplicate log of the login at 06:52:41 from different log file. No new malicious activity.

SSH login using a public key suggests remote access via valid credentials, potential lateral movement.
Session opened for user phopkins with root UID; likely indicating privilege escalation or persistent access using valid credentials.

Session closed for user phopkins, indicates logout; part of normal behavior after previous login.
SSH session closed for user phopkins, consistent with expected logout after a session; not anomalous alone.

Outbound APT User-Agent used for downloading legitimate Ubuntu packages; matches policy rule but is benign system behavior.
